entry.title: Information Overload 2011-01-23
entry.content:
• “All-Seeing Blimp Could Be Afghanistan’s Biggest Brain”:http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/01/all-seeing-blimp/
    The US military has plans to deploy a giant “blimp”:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blimp over Afghanistan. While kinda cool from a technological perspective, this is also quite scary.
  • “I Can Crack Your App With Just A Shell (And How To Stop Me)”:http://kswizz.com/post/2785664228/hacking-mac-apps
    If you like OSX, assembler and security, you’ll probably find this interesting. Also contains hints for developers on how to make their apps harder to crack.
  • “The China Paradox”:http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/01/19/the_china_paradox?page=full
    All the paradoxes are exactly what makes China so interesting. I still find it to be a baffling place, even after 5 years of Sinology at uni and having lived there for a year.
  • “Key figures in new Tunisia government”:http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12216095
    Short biographies of some of the key figures of the new Tunisian government. Interesting side note: Slim Amamou, Secretary of state for sport and youth is a member of the Tunisian Pirate Party.
  • “How Facebook Ships Code”:http://framethink.wordpress.com/2011/01/17/how-facebook-ships-code/
    Very interesting insights into Facebook’s developer driven culture.
  • “Natur aus der Fabrik”:http://www.zeit.de/2009/06/N-Milch?page=all
    Since we all should be more aware of what we put into our bodies, here’s an article about modern milk production (in German).
  • “A manifesto for the simple scribe”:http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/blog/2011/jan/19/manifesto-simple-scribe-commandments-journalists
    25 commandments for journalists by “Tim Radford”:http://www.guardian.co.uk/profile/timradford.
  • “The decline effect and the scientific method”:http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/12/13/101213fa_fact_lehrer?currentPage=all
    The scientific method also has to hold up to scientific scrutiny.
  • “State of the World 2011: Bruce Sterling and Jon Lebkowsky”:http://www.well.com/conf/inkwell.vue/topics/400/State-of-the-World-2011-Bruce-St-page02.html
    I know I’m a bit late to the party, but maybe this is useful for people who missed it the first time around. Includes lots of good links.
  • “Update on Internet censorship in Iran”:https://blog.torproject.org/blog/update-internet-censorship-iran
    From the “Tor”:https://www.torproject.org/ blog.
